Laser. Lasers deal more damage the more the same target is hit with a laser weapon. If the weapon hits the same target on the following turn, its damage die increases by one step (d3 -> d4 -> d6 -> d8 -> d10 -> d12 -> 2d6 -> 2d8 -> 2d10 -> 2d12). Missile. Missiles have two different fire modes. In Targeted mode, you must spend a bonus action to lock onto a target that you can see within the hardpoint’s range. The target remains locked for one minute, or until it is successfully hit by the hardpoint or leaves the hardpoint’s range. A pilot does not require line of sight when firing a missile hardpoint at a locked target. Once locked, you can fire the hardpoint at the target as an action on your turn, dealing the hardpoint’s noted damage on a hit. In Saturation mode, you can instead spend your action to fill an area with the entire armed and ready ammunition at your disposal. Each creature in that radius must succeed on a Dexterity saving throw, taking the table’s noted damage on a failed save, or half as much on a success.

Multi-rocket. When using a multi-rocket, you can lock onto a number of targets in range equal to the hardpoints RoF value as a bonus action. You can choose the same target more than once, or different ones. Make a single attack roll for all targets. Each target takes the noted damage in the hardpoints entry. For every additional missile locked onto a single target, that target takes an extra die of the hardpoint’s damage. When calculating when to reload, a multi rocket hardpoint only counts as making one attack per action, regardless of its RoF value, unless it uses the saturation fire mode.

BeanBag Toaster. The Beanbag toaster is an experimental hardpoint of gnomish design; accidentally created after trying to develop a more efficient toast-delivery system. A battery of toasters welded together forms the hardpoints base, while a funnel brimming with gunpowder-filled beanbags acts as the hardpoints auto-loader.

When fired, the beanbags are briefly cooked inside the toasting mechanism, catching fire before catapulting out towards a target and exploding violently on impact. As an action, you can choose to fire the beanbag toaster at one target you can see within range. For the next minute, the beanbag toaster will continue to fire flaming beanbags, choosing a different target within 20ft of the previous target it fired at during the beginning of each of your turns (no additional actions required by you). If there are no other targets within range or line of sight, the hardpoint will continue to fire at the same target it fired at previously if possible. It otherwise fires wildly into the air.

Make a single ranged attack roll against your chosen target each time this hardpoint fires. On a hit, the target is hit by 3d6 flaming beanbags. Each beanbag deals 1d4 bludgeoning damage and 1d4 fire damage.

description.p: Trailers are upgrade modules pulled by ATUMs, much like a conventional trailer. Each trailer can store up to 500lbs of equipment or materials, and has a single module slot, which can be used to attach another trailer, hardpoint, upgrade module or one additional fuel tank of any size.

Unlike other modules, trailers can be targeted directly by attacks. If reduced to 0 hit points, trailers are reduced to a small scrap pile, and any separated trailers must be reattached to an ATUM before they can be moved again or the ATUM has access to any modules installed on them. Trailers have an AC of 15, 55 (10d10) hit points, and increase the length of the ATUM by 10 feet per trailer.

When a trailer is installed, you must also install an additional mobility type for it. The ATUM does not benefit from any features of this mobility type, and can only ever move at the lowest speed available to it.
An ATUM can pull a number of trailers at the same time equal to its chassis Strength modifier.
